drug.name: Amylocaine
drug.description:
Despite the introduction of using cocaine injections for regional anesthesia in 1884, non-addictive substitutes were sought after immediately [L1882]. Finally, in 1903 the world's first synthetic and non-addictive local anesthetic, amylocaine, was synthesized and patented under the name Forneaucaine by Ernest Fourneau at the Pasteur Institute [L1882]. Elsewhere in English speaking countries it was referred to as Stovaine, given the meaning of the French word 'fourneau' as 'stove' in English [L1882].
Although amylocaine could be administered topically or injected, it was most widely used for spinal anesthesia [L1882]. Even though it certainly possessed less severe side effects than cocaine [L1882], the eventual development and clinical use of newer, more effective, and even safer local anesthetics like lidocaine, bupivicaine, and prilocaine in the 1940s and 1950s superseded and made the use of amylocaine obsolete.

article.citation: Coleman RB: SPINAL ANAESTHESIA BY STOVAINE. Br Med J. 1925 Mar 21;1(3351):548-9.
Butterworth JF 4th, Strichartz GR: Molecular mechanisms of local anesthesia: a review. Anesthesiology. 1990 Apr;72(4):711-34.

textbook.citation: Gary R. Strichartz (1987). Local Anesthetics. Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.

drug.indication: The most common indication for the usage of amylocaine was spinal anesthesia [A32277].
drug.pharmacodynamics: Like all other local anesthetics, amylocaine acts as a membrane stabilizing drug that reversibly decreases the rate of depolarization and depolarization of excitable membranes [A32278]. In this way, the conduction of neuronal signals for certain bodily movements can be blocked [A32278]. In particular, when administered for spinal anesthesia, the resultant anesthesia can typically extend from the chest to the legs [A32278].
drug.mechanism-of-action: In particular, amylocaine, much like other local anesthetics, bind and blockade voltage gated sodium channels located in the excitable membranes of various sensory receptors [A32278]. Once blocked, the influx of sodium across the channels and membrane is inhibited [A32278]. Because the influx of sodium is necessary to facilitate neuronal action potentials and signal conduction across sensory receptor membranes, the influx inhibition subsequently prevents the body reactions that would normally result from the neuronal signals [A32278].
drug.toxicity: A lack of detailed information regarding the specificities of amylocaine relate to a lack of information on its pharmacokinetics at the time of its primary use in the early 1900s [T146].

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 1 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: Mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient.

go-classifier.description: positive regulation of defense response to virus by host

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 10 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: Tetrodotoxin-resistant channel that mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which sodium ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. Plays a role in neuropathic pain mechanisms.

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 11 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: This protein mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which sodium ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. It is a tetrodotoxin-resistant sodium channel isoform. Also involved, with the contribution of the receptor tyrosine kinase NTRK2, in rapid BDNF-evoked neuronal depolarization.

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 2 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: Mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient.

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 4 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: This protein mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. This sodium channel may be present in both denervated and innervated skeletal muscle.

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 5 subunit alpha
polypeptide.general-function: Voltage-gated sodium channel activity involved in sa node cell action potential
polypeptide.specific-function: This protein mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. It is a tetrodotoxin-resistant Na(+) channel isoform. This channel is responsible for the initial upstroke of the action potential. Channel inactivation is regulated by intracellular calcium levels.

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 8 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: Mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. In macrophages and melanoma cells, isoform 5 may participate in the control of podosome and invadopodia formation.

synonyms.synonym: Sodium channel protein type VIII subunit alpha
Voltage-gated sodium channel subunit alpha Nav1.6

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha
polypeptide.specific-function: Mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. It is a tetrodotoxin-sensitive Na(+) channel isoform. Plays a role in pain mechanisms, especially in the development of inflammatory pain (By similarity).

synonyms.synonym: Sodium channel protein type IX subunit alpha
Voltage-gated sodium channel subunit alpha Nav1.7
